sequentialTasks.title: OPTIMIZE: Timer Wheel Implementation
sequentialTasks.description: Replace O(log n) timer heap with O(1) hierarchical timing wheel for improved timer throughput. Benefits high-frequency timer scenarios (thousands of timers/sec).
sequentialTasks.decision: Timer wheel provides O(1) vs O(log n) operations, but only benefits workloads with >10,000 concurrent timers. This codebase's maximum observed is 1000 (stress test), and typical JavaScript usage is <100 concurrent timers.
reasoning: Current heap performance: O(log 1000) ≈ 10 comparisons ≈ 100ns per operation
Timer pool already eliminates allocation overhead
Timer wheel requires 300-500 LOC for hierarchical implementation
Fixed tick resolution introduces precision tradeoffs
No profiling data shows timer operations as bottleneck
Maintenance burden: more code = more bugs, harder to maintain
JavaScript event loops rarely exceed 100 concurrent timers
sequentialTasks.recommendation: Revisit if profiling shows timer count > 10,000 as bottleneck
sequentialTasks.verification: Analysis documented. Current timerHeap + timerPool implementation is adequate.

expansionTasks.title: EXPAND: Timer Coalescing for Same-Delay Timers
expansionTasks.description: Analyze if timer coalescing (batching timers with identical deadlines) is worth implementing.
expansionTasks.decision: Timer coalescing would batch timers scheduled at the exact same nanosecond-precision deadline. This is not worth implementing because: (1) timers rarely have identical nanosecond deadlines, (2) heap operations are O(log n) which is already fast, (3) CHANGELOG already documents 'Same-delay timers not guaranteed FIFO' as intentional.
reasoning: Heap provides O(log n) insert and O(log n) pop - already efficient
Same-delay collisions require nanosecond-precision timing matches
JS ecosystem never expects same-delay timers to be FIFO (browser-specific)
Implementation would add complexity for minimal benefit
expansionTasks.verification: Analyzed codebase and spec requirements. Timer coalescing not justified.

expansionTasks.title: EXPAND: SetInterval Drift Compensation
expansionTasks.description: Analyze if SetInterval requires drift compensation to align with spec.
expansionTasks.decision: Current SetInterval implementation is spec-compliant. HTML5 spec says to schedule 'timeout milliseconds from now' - not aligned to original start time. Both browsers and Node.js accumulate drift (callback runs, THEN delay is waited). This is correct behavior.
reasoning: HTML5 spec: schedule next invocation 'timeout ms from now'
Browsers: callback completes, then wait delay milliseconds
Node.js: same behavior - no drift compensation
Current implementation: schedules next execution after callback completes
Result: cumulative drift, matching spec and all major runtimes
expansionTasks.verification: Analyzed spec and compared with current implementation. Already spec-compliant.
